name: NME Test Broadcast
summary: Ricky, Steve and Karl recorded a two-hour radio show as part of the test transmissions for the new radio station NME Radio.

transcript.content: Hello.
Testing. This is a special transmission. A special one-off show with me, Ricky Gervais, Stephen Merchant.
Hello there.
And the little bald Manc twat that is the shaven monkey known as Karl Pilkington.
Alright.

Now, Rick, just a quick question because if people have just stumbled across this, perhaps on the, uh internet, or on their, uh TV channel, they're probably going to be a little bit alarmed by what you've said there. You come straight in with little bald Manc twat and a lot of people don't know who
That little bald Manc twat is.  So maybe you should clarify?

Well, um, how can I say it.. I, I'm, I'm Ricky Gervais. You probably know me from such shows as The Office and Extras, cameos in the odd film. Um, my, uh long-term partner - not in that way - Stephen Merchant.
Not in that way. Uh, Stephen Merchant, yes. I was involved with some of these projects, um, but I've not been in a film.
And, uh, we met Karl when we went back to XFM as conquering heroes. We were, we were let go when uh, XFM changed hands.

And then, um, we did The Office and then we came back and we were big shots. No longer did we need to run the desk or press any buttons. Um, so we were assigned, um, how can I put this? Uh, like a, a stupid lackey?
Yes, yes, um, proper str- I mean probably the person who was lowest on the rung.
I'd have thought so.
At the radio station.
They said oh, give it to them, no one wants to work Saturdays.
The caretaker didn't work Saturdays.
Ricky laughs
So they gave us Karl.
And we met Karl.

And, um, I was first struck by the roundness of his head. I'll be honest. I thought this is a bald man. Um, a little round-headed, bald freak of a man. He opened his mouth. He spoke funny. Um. Actually he spoke without opening his mouth, that was the second thing that struck me.
Steve laughs
He just had this slack-jawed gimpness about him. Words came out. Um, they were-
I think, I think they got the idea now, anyway.
Was, what-
Ricky laughs
Do you feel that that was a balanced, uh, explanation of your meeting with us? Or would you like to offer any extra detail there, Karl?
Um... Well, with every meeting there's a, there's a different story, i'nt there? Um... the way you sort of looked at me and thought, "He's weird." I saw Steve...
Ricky laughs
It was like a triangle. Ricky was looking at me, I was looking at you, uh, thinking, "That's weird." Uh...
It seems, um-
And yeah, that's-
-a little unjust that I'm the one, I- you know, why aren't you having to go at Ricky for being fat and old?
Just because, no, I'm just saying on the first meeting-
Right.
It's like a museum, innit? Everybody rushes to the weird stuff first.
Ricky laughs
And uh-
I love the fact that you're putting yourself firmly in that category as well, though. Oh, I love that. That's, that's great. Like something out of Reservoir Dogs, everyone looking at someone else.
But you don't feel that way about me anymore?
No, I've got used to it now.
Ricky laughs
That's- that's what I'm saying.
No, I'm saying, you, you've, that whatever your accusations of weirdness were, are they all... unfounded?
It moves. It moves on, don't it? It's like, like anything. You get, you get used to, to a look, don't you? Um, I watch a lot of programmess on stuff that people have up with them and-
You only watch programmes

About people that got something wrong with them. That is what you do. If ever you say "did you see that thing last night?" it's going to be something like the the the 'kid who was born with too many legs' or 'the the baby with an arse for a head'. It's always going to be stuff like that.
Yeah
It's like there was a program on a bit back, about a fellow who had a rather funny head and what have you, and I lived in a small village. And nobody double taked anymore because you get used to it.
What was up with his head?
Jut had like a... Sort of looked like the new Elephant Man. He sort of gone for that look.
Ricky laughs
He'd gone for that look! What was he doing in the morning? Just eat a bun sort of shave
No he just... All I'm saying is, people in his village. It wasn't a big village. People used to it and they no longer stared. And that's what I'm saying with you.
But it's interesting that, because you've you say you've acclimatized to my so-called weirdness- I don't know what weirdness that is, I've still not grasped that... But Ricky continues...
It's the eyes.
What?
Ricky bursts laughing
It's just the eyes.
(laughs) He started listing shit!

What are you... I hadn't had a go at you and your stupid f*****g round head like a f*****g orange. Which is the thing which perpetually entertains Ricky. Ricky is never acclimatized to you, is that fair, Rick?

Yeah, I love it. I just, I can't get enough of him. Because I see different things. Every time I look at Karl, sometimes I see like a completely sort of like spherical object, right? Like honestly, like some sort of pumpkin on you know... like Halloween. And then I see him, I see flat straight on...
With a pumpkin, Rick... When a Jack-o-Lantern sits outside someone's house right? There is a certain light behind the eyes.
Ricky laughs
Not with Karl.
And then sometimes he looks like a plate. Do you know what I mean? Like, you know, a clay plate that a child has made.
When they've made a face on the plate, you know, using their food.
Or a biscuit. Like one of those biscuits you know those novelty biscuits you can buy for your birthday?
Sure, with some eyes and a smile.
Yeah. But that's not the I think that's not the biggest thing about Karl... It isn't his physically, it isn't the roundness of his head, it isn't the gimpness of his slack-jawed face...
It's not even his hairy body and sort of like chimp-like gait. It is...
Although, those are all key features.

These are all key features.  But it's his incredible mind. And I think... Maybe over the next two hours or so. If you haven't heard of Jarl, then I think you're in for a treat. If you've heard a little Karl, then you're already being treated I think, by the fact that he is present on this special broadcast.
Rick can I suggest that we take a pause there? Play some music. Come back, we'll talk some more.
Oh, this isn't just about Karl. We're playing some great tunes!
Arctic Monkeys - Fluorescent Adolescent. Talking of monkeys: we're here with Karl Pilkington.
Steve laughs
I say we: I'm Ricky Gervais, with me: Stephen Merchant
Hello

Doing a special, one-off broadcast. Now,  it's special in the sense that - I don't know why special I started that sentence, I've no, you know, I really I had no backup... - It's not a particularly special. We've done this thousands of times.
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
Day?
No, I've never, I've never seen you have a great day. It doesn't matter what ya... It's unbelievable. You're whinging all the time. Miserable.
Well.
Nothing impresses you. Nothing at all. The best I've ever heard you was, "It was alright, that."
Well, tell us about the, the last time you had a great day. What was the last great day you had where you thought, "Ooh, I must end this by giving some money to homeless fella."
Um... I mean, yeah, I don't have a great day.
Ricky and Steve laugh
See?
But what I mean is, a day when I go, "Do you know what? I'm quite content."
Ricky and Steve laugh
That's amazing!
And, and I-
That's a long way from a good day.
That- that is the equivalent of him skipping along.
No, I, every night before I nod off, I lie there and I think, what sort of a day have I had? And I'll go through it and I'll go, yeah, that was alright.
How boring is that?
SO boring.
No, it's good. You gotta do that. Otherwise, what was the point of the day?
So-
If you're never gonna look back on it and go, "What have I done? Yeah, that was alright."
Ricky laughs
What's the point of it happening?
But how often do you go, "Wow! I've really achieved a lot today!"
Not often, but-
Because I remember one day, just one day at random, you told us you'd been to the cobblers and back.
Steve laughs
I didn't even know cobblers still existed.
Yeah, that was a 24-hour period we were talking about there.
Um-
You kept a diary. It-it mainly consisted of, "Had a chip butty in a, in a café with Suzanne," and then you talk about an old woman you saw.
No, I- I've-
That was your day.
I've made it a thing that I do now that  I like to learn something-
Go on then.
-every day and then-
Go on then. What have you learnt today?
Well, I haven't done anything yet.
Brilliant.
But what I'm saying is-
What, what did you learn yesterday?
I've learned
You're not a generous man. You're a mean bastard. You don't repay-
And that's coming from Steve Merchant.
I'm just saying, as long as- I always think, if you've learnt something-
Yeah.
-then the day's not been wasted. Someone, someone famous said that.
What have you learnt yesterday? What have you learnt yesterday?
Um... it was the what's it? Something you told me about the uh, the monkey arm.
Right, yeah. There's uh, um, scientists, um, have done the first brain/robot interface. They've put like 100 electrodes on the part of the cortex
That is, um, uh, for, uh, your, your motor system. And they put it on a monkey's brain, and through the power of thought, he learnt how to use a robot arm.
Wow.
So just by thought, just like, you do your own arm-
Yep.

-you know. And uh, it was, it took him a few days. Not years. In a few days, this, this monkey was making this robot arm pick up grapes and put it in his own mouth through the power of thought, right? Karl went, "Did he have his own arms?" I went, "Yeah." He went, "Well, then, he's lazy then."
Steve laughs
Don't you think it's a bit wasted on a chimp? One, what's it doing? All they ever do is eat or chuck shit about. So, why give them a decent new robotic arm?
Well who are you going to give it to?
I just mean give it to something that, that is going to get more use out of it.
What, a giraffe?
What-
No, something more... if, if they could link that up to a worm, I'd go, "That's good."
Well, how could a worm think to use a robot arm?
Listen to me.
They can't think!
Hang on, I'd like to know-
Well this is-
I'd like to how this would work.
How do you know? How do you know?
What I'm saying is, a worm's never had an arm.
You're a maniac!
I'm not, I-
Think what you're saying! You wish a worm had an arm for a day!
No, I, no. All I'm saying is, if we're gonna faff about here and get animals, giving them extra arms, don't-
They weren't giving a monkey an extra arm! They were testing this theory that they could make the first computer/brain interface.
I don't...
The thought went from the brain, through a computer, and made this arm work. That's incredible. The upshots are-are-inc-you could-you could really have bionic arms. You could
Have um, amputees having perfectly working, dextrous limbs?
And your response to that is?
I'd just say-
(mocking tone) Give it to a worm!
I'd just say, I'd be more, I'd-I'd sort of be fascinated about seeing it more, if they said, "look at what the worms wants to do with an arm, if it had one."
(Ricky and Steve laugh)
Oh, Karl!
The w-
I honestly don't know-
But how-
-how your brain wor- I think we should give it to you and see what you do with the arm.
What? I tell you what I've read. H-here we go-
How would a worm, how would a worm, how could a worm have an arm Karl? It would-
It wouldn't have an arm! The monkey didn't have an arm, it was a robot arm, that they'd setup on-
Right. Let's, let me p- explain it like this. I wish they'd've picked something else. Maybe not a worm, but they always seem to do the tests on the wrong animals.
No, they do it on the thi- closest thing to the human being it, th-they can.
They've done- I'll tell you what I read. D'y'know how I say, "I like to learn something every, every-
Yeah.
- day" and what have ya?
Yeah.
A few weeks ago, it was about how a worm, th-they've given it anti-aging cream.
Right?
When have you ever seen an old worm?
(Ricky bursts out laughing)
How do we know if it's any good?
(Ricky keeps laughing)
I could not tell you the age of a worm. I've seen loads of 'em.
(Ricky and Steve laugh)
Give it t' a tortoise.
Play a record.
Bob Dylan - Positively 4th Street
Bob Dylan - Positively 4th Street.
I actually um, Rick, was in uh, Vietnam a couple of weeks ago.
Oh, yeah.

And I know you- I don't know if this was thanks to your campaign, but I did pass somewhere- It was admittedly a European person, but as I passed they went, "Oi, oi! Karl Pilkington's got a head like a (bleep)fucking(/bleep) orange!"
That's amazing.
Which is lovely to see-
And that's in-
I've had it all the way 'round the world.
-that's in Vietnam. What were you doing in Vietnam?
Ehhhh, y'know, just a- heard there was a war. Went over to see if that was uh, wrapped up. They finished that a while ago.
So you've been to Vietnam. You went to a-
Popped down to Cambodia at the same time.
Cuba, yeah. Cambodia. Uh, Kenya. Wh-wh-wh- well I was wondering, would you ever consider going to a holiday destination where you didn't have to have injections in the stomach to get in?
Well, you know what? I am an adventurer, by spirit. I'm a sort of Indiana Jones figure and um, plus someone was paying for it.
(Ricky laughs)
(chuckles) A-and we did it-
(Steve clears throat)
Pardon me. We did in, uh high class luxury.
Didya?

There was no slumming it. I felt a bit bad because I was worried that I wouldn't see the real Vietnam. But I did, I did see the real Vietnam, from the air-conditioned 4x4 that I was being driven to my five-star hotel, in.
And what's it like?
It's great; it's really good! I mean, obviously, y'know, the war was long time ago, so they've got back on the uh, y'know back on their- Uppers? I don't know what I mean by that. But anyway-
No, that's the other way around. If you're on your uppers, innit- Yeah.
Back on? Anyway, n-no it's doing well. A lot of nice people, uh, generous people. Y'know, obviously there's poverty.
Yeah.
Um- there's a couple of things over there, I think, which would really intrigue you Karl.
(Ricky laughs through his nose)
And I think it's a great shame that you're not more adventurous as a traveler, because I think it would really open your eyes.
You're having a laugh. He has about nine holidays a year.
Yeah, but he goes to the same place, doesn't he? Some rock in the Mediterranean.
Yeah, it's safe. I know Vietnam's there-
There's nothing there!
I know but, but I don't sort of, what I've seen of Vietnam- I had a mate who went to somewhere like that. He showed me a picture. He had a picture of him-
(Ricky beginning to laugh)
-uh, walking 'round with a bag of locust-
(Ricky laughs)
-that he'd been sold.
And that's, that's to eat.
Ricky trying to stifle laughter
Well, I did I did actually utter the phrase at one point; "I think that gecko's repeating on me."
Ricky bursts out laughing
That's what I mean.

So, I am quite exotic. I don't mind. I tell you what I didn't do though, I think I would be fascinated to have seen you down there. There's a place in Vietnam, just outside of Hanoi called Snake Village, right? And it is a long, long tradition in Vietnamese culture of eating snakes. In fact, one of the tourist even said, one of the guides actually said, we will eat anything and they eat snakes over there and I'm not just talking about tiny little ones...

I mean, proper great, big mammoth snakes, sometimes even king cobras, which I think may even be endangered in some parts of the world. And anyway in snake Village you go over there. I didn't go because I was just a bit too squeamish, you sit down, they bring up great big snake, you choose it, like you would a lobster, they bring you that snake. They give it... they give it a bit of a demonstration, then they slit open in front of you.
That's disgusting
The blood dribbles into a cup. And then, if you're the guest of honour, they take the still-beating heart and they make you drink it from a glass.
Yeah. You see....
That's disgusting
I've never fancied that.
No.
I've never sort of thought, you know what...?
Karl makes eating noises
I just think it's... it's not a holiday that. It's like, endurance.
Ricky bursts out laughing
I don't...

I'm not suggesting that you would enjoy that. I'm saying that there are many of these interesting. You know, exotic worlds out there. You just stay cosseted in your tiny little world and whinge about everyone else, "Oooo this and that..." You've got no real empathy. I mean I went to some extraordinary places in Vietnam. There's quite a lot of floating villages.
Yeah.
Villages that are actually floating on the water, where the fishermen live.
Well he's a trouble with his boiler. There's was a big leak in your flat wasn't there?

But that's fine looking at stuff like that. All I'm saying is when it comes to the like the point when I'm getting hungry, don't be serving a snake's head. I'd love to see a little floating village. But why is it every restaurant you go in the go, you know, "Do you want some crispy, Ant?" Sea urchin's, you know, some mate had one of them. They said it's sort of alive when you're eating it. You have to hit it on the head to knock it out a bit and eat it before it wakes up again. I don't want a meal where you're sort of having to do that to it. Not going to enjoy it thinking, is it waking up yet? I haven't finish me starter. Oh its rolling about a bit it.
Hit it on the head again.
But this shows you ignorance Karl because Vietnamese food is not like that at all. Is it? I'm just talking about one particular exotic restaurant.
What was your last holiday? A couple weeks ago wasn't it?
Er yeah. It was a cheap one though.
Go on, where did you go?
It was only 250 quid.
Yeah, brilliant. Go on.
Just a place in Minorca.
You don't want to waste money do you?
Minorca, it's just....
But you've been there before haven't you?
Errr.... No. I don't think I have.
You've basically been to the same places over there.
Yeah, there's not..... I mean, I'll... yeah, you're right. I mean, there's there was nothing there to see.
It was, it was just, even the weather wasn't that good but..
Steve and Ricky laugh
So it was a waste of time.
I don't know why I went.
Ricky bursts out laughing
No wonder it was 250 quid!
Ricky talking and laughing
"I don't know why I went!"
But it's an experience...
So you and Suzanne went away for an idyllic holiday. It was 250 pounds, all in for a week was it?
Uh huh
Weather wasn't very good. There was nothing to see.
It was a shit hole.
Right, what did you do?
Erm... I just sat outside and I was watching...
In the rain?
You didn't even need to hire a villa then. You could be just like...
No. It sort of...
...pitched up and say "Can I sit here?"
We had our own space and for the first day was alright.
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
Hear him out.
Go on...

Yeah, so if your ears can't do their job, it's like a well-behaved kid. It sits there. It's quite happy. It's not interested in what's going on around it. Set the earplugs out - they go mental. What's that noise? What noise? Go and have a look - eyes! go and have a look!
I don't know what you're talkin' about. This is the ramblings of a Maniac.
Uhhh...
Can you tell your brain to tell your mouth to talk some sense?
Well which order would you say it works in?
But it's all working at the same time, isn't it?
No, but your brains at the beginning of the - if it was a circuit, your brain's at the beginning.

No not necessarily. Not with hearing something. Your ears come first. But they're passive. Your ears are merely receptacles for sound, right. There are conduit to the brain. So hearing is only thought, hearing isn't the air waves hitting your eardrum.
Can't block it out.
No what I'm saying is, that's a passive thing. Your fingers, when it touches something, it's your brain...
That develops that information. Your fingers aren't going - Oh! I recognize that it's a piece of cheese, it just touches it and your brain recognizes it, it's all done in the brain.
Long pause.
Mmm.
No not convinced?
I'm just -
That information is still being worked on by the brain.
Yeah.
All I can do is tell you the way I work and I know if I'm sat in a quiet place-
No karl!
-with nothing around me.
[talking over karl] No, you can't tell me the way your brain works.
My ears, my ears get bored.
That makes no sense at all.
I'm telling you, if I'm in a quiet place, my brain is happier. It can, it can focus on what it's doing. The ears  almost go - "There's nowt to hear here, call it a day".
[laughing] No they don't!
The eyes are going "well there's nowt to see outside".

Just, just chill out. Whereas if there's a noise outside - if it's a noisy Street, everything's kicking in, me brain's getting annoyed, me brains-me ears are going - "what's that racket?" - Me eyes are thinking, "oh what was that scream? What's happened?"
What's your nose doing?
Why's your eyes thinking "what's the scream"?
What?
Why are your eyes getting concerned with noise?
It wants to see what the ears have heard.
Ricky laughs
The Cure - Lullaby
The Cure - lullaby on NME radio with me Ricky Gervais. Stephen Merchant.
Hello. And Karl Pilkington.
Alright
Now...
Straight after your holiday you were - you got home and then came out to visit me in in Boston.
Yeah.
On the set of my film I was doing.
Hmm.
How was that?
Well I didn't want to do it, did I? He called up and said, "do you want to come out?".
"Do a favor for me". Ricky said "do a favor for me" you thought - no.

Errm, well, no, I didn't - I didn't just go "no", I sort of said "what is it?" And he said, "oh, you can just have a part" and it's like - what's the point though? I'm not an actor. I can't act. What's the point?
[inaudible]
So anyway, he said, "all right don't bother" and a week later called back and he says bring Suzanne with you if you want. Have a holiday. So I thought. Yeah, I could treat Suzanne to that.
I thought a little part-
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
Sure.

Uh, but this time I thought I'd embrace this and I've brought you something, as to show you. It's not really going to be very helpful on the uh, on the NME radio. But I've, I'll start- I decided to wear a hat.
Oh God.
I thought I'd buy a hat.
Oh God.
And wear a hat. And I thought that- I bought this last minute, as I was just, before we got on the plane, I was doing some shopping. I thought I need to, you know, cos you can-
You think, you think you'd be summat like from a Graham Greene novel.
Right. Exactly.
They'd go um, (in a vague accent) "They call him the Englishman."
Exactly.
"He's the wisest-". And yeah, exactly.
Exactly. So I thought I- cos you can kind of reinvent yourself when you're abroad in some way-
Yeah.
-can't ya, you know-
Yeah.
And um, so this is the hat I got.
Christ.
(plastic bag ruffling)
Maybe you should look away for a second and I'll put it on.
Okay.
And then you can uh... Now, bear in mind, it is a bit battered because it's been in bags and stuff.
Sure.
(Ricky laughs)
Steve, what are you thinking? Right.
No, it is a bit battered and damaged, I admit.
Right, okay. How can I um? Right. I uh- It looks like a cross between summat Miss Marple would wear-
(Steve laughs)
That's nonsense!
No, it does. It looks a bit like that. Um, and there's a beer, with a bloke drinking- What's that called? Moretti beer?
I think you're thinking of the Hofmeister bear.
No, I'm not. It uh- it looks like Miss Marple's hat.
It doesn't look like Miss Marple's hat!
It does.
It's kind of moddy, isn't it? It's, it's a bit mod-ish.
It's not. It's a tweed thing that comes down that-
(Steve laughs)
-an old lady would wear.
(while chuckling) It's not tweed. What're you talking about?
It was a librar- a librarian lady would wear in the 1930s.
It's not tweed.
I have never seen any-, tha- you didn't really buy that, did you, to wear?
I did.
No, you didn't.
Yes I did.
Right. Um, can I take a picture of this, and I'll put it on my website? Right. I am now taping this on a camcorder. I will put this up on rickygervais.com.

I disagree. I think this genuinely looks good. I think it makes me look a bit like, say Tom Waits, or um, Farmer Barleymow. The point is this, right? I'm wearing the hat; I'm looking good, okay? But people, obviously, they can sense that I'm a moneyed tourist. They can see how good I look, and they know I got a little bit of money in me pocket. Can afford to buy hats, you know, and everything.
(Ricky suppresses laughter)
So, obviously, I'm always a target for people trying to get money from me, stuff like that, which is always a-
Mm, then they knew.

-a hassle, innit? Now I find it very difficult tipping when I'm abroad. I don't really understand what the rules are with tipping. And that's a big anxiety, for me. And also I have problems with the conversion, y'know, because obviously when you go abroad- so um, the Vietnamese dong-
(Ricky giggles)
Come on. There's nothin- that, there's nothing funny about that. That's just what it's called, right? For 63 US dollars, you can get a million dong, right? That's a lot of dong.
(Ricky nervously laughs)
So um, I'm packing like-
A huge dong.
(Steve laughs)
I-I- I got like, you know, two million dong, like in me money belt under me shirt, right?
Yeah you- you to- so, so let me get this image right. You were wearing that hat and a bum bag?
Yes but, well no I-, no I-, no-
You must've looked pretty cool.
I don't have a bum bag. I have a, I have a um, I have a money belt that I wear underneath the t-shirt-
Right.
So as not to see, y'know, so people don't think I've got any money on me.
Yeah.
And if I get mugged I can just go, "I haven't got any money on me". Because they would never think to look-
Under the t-shirt?
-underneath the shirt and see the money belt.
But that's still out of reach, innit? Over there?
(Ricky laughs)
Yeah.
[~3 mins of missing transcription]

I was a bit worried so, I-I- was thinking of asking for the money, you know, for some change. But I didn't think that was appropriate. So um, but then I was worried because I was thinking, what if all the other drivers within his organization find out that I've given him like 20 dollars? They're all going to be expecting a big tip.
Yeah.

So that was a big worry. But more than that we also had a guide with us so he was bound to find out, how that is. Right now I don't have any dollars left. And I thought, well, I've given that by 20, I gotta give the guy who's been talking English to us, showing us round, helping us out, I got give him even more-
-right. I ended up giving him a million dong.
And how much is that?
$63. I tipped someone a million dollars.
So he's a millionaire now.
Yeah.
(Steve chuckles)
I-I- made someone a millionaire through my generosity.
Well, so well, so did I; he's sitting over there.
(Steve chuckles)
That's absolutely right.
But he doesn't want to give anything back. So I know how you feel mate.
Neil Young - Old Man
Neil Young - Old Man. Karl. Now you know traditionally at the zoo they have to, um, dart a dangerous animal. A lion, or, or a gorilla, or whatever--
They have to what?
They have to dart it.
Oh yeah. Yeah, yeah.

To um, to um, take blood samples and check its health and stuff. So it's very stressful for the animal and quite dangerous to give it an anesthetic like that. So what they've started doing now, there's a bug, right? Like a type of beetle and uh, it's a bloodsucker. It's a little vampire bug, okay? It's about 3 cm long. What they do is they tie piece of string around it. They let it go into the cage, on the chimp. It sucks the chimp's blood without the chimp even knowing. They pull it back and they take the blood sample from it.
They've taught it to do that?
Well, they've not taught it to do anything; that's its nature. You put it near a warm blooded mammal, it will suck its blood. So they've just tied a string to it so they can get it back.
And how often does it have to do that a day?
Well, I don't know, I don't know, uh-- Why are these the important questions?
(Steve laughs)
Just because, just because-
Isn't that incredible? That they've got, they've got this amazing symbiotic relationship with a bug because that's what-
Is it the same one? Say if there's eight chimps-
No- oh, Jesus. Karl! Listen to me!
No, let him- I wanna here these questions.
I'm just sayin' if there's eight chimps in there-
Yeah.
Eh, one beetle. By about number five, that's going to be sick of eating.
Well then they probably have different beetles and they let it, and-- Karl! I don't know why this is the, the avenue of questioning.
It just, I'll tell ya why it annoys me, because-
It annoys him.
The other concern is, uh that beetle. It might be enjoyin', y'know, getting the blood and what have ya. What happens if-if- one of them's got, got AIDS?
What, one of the-
One of the chimps. That's where it came from. So say if there's a-
Well then, then they'll know. And they'll say, "oh, this chimp's got AIDS. Let's"-
But what about the beetle?
What? Are you saying you're worried that the beetle will contract AIDS?
Well, I-I don't know if that's how it works. But all I'm saying is you get a dirty chimp in there, eh-
(Ricky giggles)
It's got, it's got a touch of that. And, and, and, and the, and the, the beetle gets it. And all I'm sayin' is it seems a bit unfair. He's-
What are you worried about? The beetle? Working hard? It's eating what it likes.

Because this, because this is the same as getting in foreigners to make cheap trainers, to me. They, y'know, let the beetle do what it wants. I mean, beetl- How long do they live? I read the other day about some elephant beet-
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
The problem is they haven't got any of these beetles here.
Right?
So they've had to-, instead of, uh, flying it back out-
Yeah.
-they've gone over there to try and find one to bring it back. Because of the stress an' that, that it's had and it's older.
Couldn't you put a gerbil in a beetle outfit?
(Steve laughs)
Hang on a minute!
I don't mean, I don't mean a little wig, holding a guitar.
But I don't know the full story an' that. I just know that they found this beetle that-
It just sounds unlikely that people would become this concerned about one beetle-
(laughing) I don't- I agree.
(laughing) -and it's only got half a month left.
Yeah.
It's got two weeks left, it's got to have some sex! We have got to give this beetle some sex because, God damn it, it's a beetle. What was found on a boat with some bananas?
Yeah, I don't know why-
It deserves sex before it dies.
I don't know why he cares more than a blood sucking beetle than a chimpanzee that's underneath!
I just can't believe people are flying out to Japan and where have they come from?
Why d'you-, why d'you care so much about beetles all of a sudden?
Only because they were mentioned. And I just thought, y'know whilst we're on the beetle tip, let's y'know, let's, discuss 'em.
What d'you mean its legs were going as well?
That's what they do. That shows signs of like it needs, it needs a, uh a woman. Ehh, it's never had one before, which is weird. That's, that's, that's what I was gonna say, uhh-
Go on.
It knew even though it didn't.
(Ricky laughs)
And you're talking about me brain and me ears and all that. There's an example-
Go on.
-of how the beetle's not in charge. There's something else going on in its body.
Well that's called instinct.
Yeah.
But that's true in a beetle but it shouldn't be true in a human bein'.

But it is though, innit? Otherwise how did the first baby survive? How did, how did, how are we here now? Because you look at babies and they're spoiled rotten. I'm sick of it, the way they don't do anything for ages. They wouldn't survive.
(Ricky laughs through his mouth)
A kangaroo comes out, it's hopping around in about two hours. Babies, they sit there for months.
But there's a very good reason for that. I've told you that.
It needs its mother.
Yeah.
If that was in a banana crate, it would have given up after about a week. What I'm saying is-
No, a couple of days.
Mmmmm-
It would've died in a couple of days, probably.

Yeah. Where as this beetle, he didn't know the outcome. He didn't know if he's ever going to see this partner. Yet even though it's been in this crate with bananas, for three and a half months, it still wants to have it away! Now if I was that, I'd be like, "I'm not in the mood anyway".
(Ricky laughs)
Why do you keep- and why do you equate yourself with a beetle? This is what I don't understand.
No, I'm not. I'm just saying how that's where nature's good. And I think th-the beetles are better than us, in a way.

We have got our brain. We've got our creativity. We've got our cognition. We've got all those things. That's, that's, that's our forte. That's where we kick in. Thought. Introspection. Art. I agree, wha- I could not live in a crate full of bananas for t-two-
Mmm.
-and a ha-. I-I uh admit that. I admit that if my mum, uh gave birth to me and then dropped me immediately in a bin, I wouldn't have survived.
Yeah.
But I don't see your point.
I just-
And I understand that beetles can do that and I can't.
Mm.
But d'y'know what? The beetles- they couldn't have (starts to laugh) written and directed The Office. So let's call it even.
Hey! All this talk of The Beatles, right, has suggested to me, let's have some more music. Here's the Rolling Stones.
Oohhhhh. Doesn't work.
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
Well you don't know what I'm selling yet.
Okay well what are you selling?
Don't get- don't get nasty.
I'm not getting nasty I'm just saying do you- do you like to write much? Do you do much writing?
Yeah I do some writing yeah I'm a writer, yeah.
Do ya?
Yeah.
Interesting, how do you do that?
Computer, I use a word processor, yeah, computer.
Karl sighs
Thanks very much, goodbye.
No no but hang on a minute just- er- do you ever- do you ever use a pen?
Sometimes I use pens yeah, but I've got loads of pens thanks, I've got a really nice pen here. Beautiful, classic-
Looks like- looks like an expensive fountain pen to me.
It's an expensive fountain pen my grandfather gave it to me-
So that's quite a special pen it sounds like- I mean it is a lovely pen and everything but the problem is, when you go out and about there's a danger that you could lose that.
That is very true but I mean I don't really take pens when I go out and about.
Have you seen these Sir? Can I interest you in some of these Sir?
Just looks like a cheap, tatty old pen, mate.
Sometimes you just want a pen that does the job, and this pen does that job. Do you want to buy some?
No I don't.
Why not?
Ricky laughs
Well cos I've got- I've just- I've just told you I've got a great pen-
Genius! Genius!
I've got a great pen already and I don't see why I need that pen. It's cheap and it's tacky and it's no use to me.
But you're saying it's cheap but do you know how cheap?
How cheap is it?
Well it depends how many you want.
Well, let's just say for the sake of argument that I wanted 50 of them.
Yeah I can do that.
What kinda deal would you do for me?
How much?
Er... 8 quid?
8 quid for 50 of those pens I could get them for about a penny down the market!

Karl you're selling- you're selling 50 pens for 8 quid. How much do they cost you? Just wanna make sure this is a good business venture for you otherwise it's pointless- how much did they cost you to buy?
Erm I got them really cheap.
But how much?
How much did I say you can have them for?
8 quid for 50.
I paid a fiver for 50.
Really? Where- this is- I'll- I'll have- I'll have- can I have them for a fiver cause I'm a mate?
Er... You can have 25 for four... fifty.
No, well no if you got them- if you got 50 pens for 5 quid can I-
I wouldn't do this as a living!
Ricky laughs
Anyway, that's the thing.
Karl, can you get me, can you get me 50 pens for a fiver then?
50 pens for a fiver?
Yeah.
It's not worth it mate.
Well no I'm a mate. You don't want to make a profit out of me do you?
It's not worth it. Er- I'm trying to run a business here I've got bills to pay.
Yeah well I'm trying to fucking write something now I'm gonna close the door in your face.
Alright you don't want a pen.
No.
Fine. Sometimes you've gotta know when to cut off and- and move on, and that's what I'd do.
So that's what you'd say to Sir Alan, is it? You always give up. When someone says-
I'll say- I'll say I met him, er, he just wasn't having it, Sir Alan.
Ricky laughs
I'd say he didn't want any pens. If you don't want any pens you're not gonna buy them.
But that's- you're a salesman, you've gotta persuade me that I need a pen, everyone needs pens.

But what about the other fella that came of the- well just lurking behind him but came out of the shower and I went "oh I'll have 50 pens for a fiver" what did you say to him? You said "not interested"-

Yeah cos it all got a bit dodgy. I don't know who this person was and that and- and he just wanted them at the going rate, what sort of a businessman would I be for me to have got the pens for 50 quid. 50 pens for a- how much?
Ricky laughs
Eight-
You're fired!
Stick it up your arse!
Clash - White Riot
Well I've enjoyed it, I must say. I've been Ricky Gervais, with me Stephen Merchant.
Goodbye!
And er- and Karl Pilkington. Erm.. If you've enjoyed this
If you've enjoyed this drivel, as much as me, which is unlikely. Because, I mean, I like being in a room with a no, no offense to you Steve, but with a couple of freaks.
Steve laughs.
None taken.
Sure thanks.
If you have, we um, we've got a little back catalog haven't we karl. Are we've done about? What is it? 24, these?
Loads. Loads of 'em.
You can go to iTunes on a little audio book. Good value for money isn't? It's a couple of quid for hours of entertainment.
I'll tell you as well, if you, if you love great music and, as I say, you know, informative chit-chat then 6 music is your destination. BBC 6 music you can check that out every Sunday afternoon.
Ricky speaks over Steve as he's plugging his radio 6 show.
Karl  got anything to plug?
Well if you don't wanna listen to the radio and you haven't got iTunes, go back to basics. Read a book.
Yeah.
It's not out yet, but, will be.
Well how are they going to read it then if it's not out yet?
Just saying it will.
Well, I'm saying they can go to iTunes NOW and get the back catalogue, and they can go to 6 Music this Sunday, so I don't know why you're saying... you might do a book. Well...
After that, after they've done all that, in and a couple of months just nip down to a book shop.
I'm not wanting a couple of months. What if they need to have it away?
Busy guy.
Like the beetle. You wouldn't say the beetle "Oh, it's alright you can have it away in a couple of months".
Alright there's another book out there as well that I did last year.
Right.
I've presume as well is the NME radio going to be on at some point?
Just check the NME for details.
Yeah or maybe go on its website
Nme.com?
Probably...
